The Caribbean islands and south Florida are bracing for their next major weather event.
It's not a hurricane, though; it's a dust storm, an enormous cloud of red sand.
And get this: It's kicked up in the Sahara Desert and rides the trade winds all the way across the Atlantic.
One person who's spent his career watching this sort of event is Dr. Joseph Prospero.
He's a professor of marine and atmospheric science at the University of Miami in Florida.
And welcome to the program.
Thank you.
So a dust storm all the way from the Sahara.
How does the dust get to Miami?
Well, during the summer months, Miami and--well, much of the tropical Atlantic and the Caribbean lies in the trade wind belt.
So in Africa, you generate dust and it gets lifted up in the atmosphere and it gets caught up in the trade wind circulation, and the dust goes where the trade wind goes.
So we get dust here in Miami.
So even though it's riding the winds, it doesn't necessarily get put out, if you will, or moistened by the clouds?
Well, when the dust-laden air interacts with a tropical storm or a random cloud in the trade winds, it will be removed by precipitation processes.
It will rain out and be deposited on the ocean surface or on islands.
And, in fact, much of the soils in the Caribbean islands is derived from African dust, so it does contribute something to the islands.

So, yes, there is the removal of dust during the transport process, but a lot of it remains in the atmosphere because a large part of the Atlantic doesn't experience much rain at this time of year, particularly the eastern Atlantic.
So it travels quite far.
So what does it look like?
Does it look simply like a hazy day?
Yes, it looks like a very hazy day, and you get very much reduced visibility.
Our school is located on Virginia Key; we're about, oh, three or four miles from the shoreline.
And when I look to downtown Miami, the buildings will be quite hazy and, you know, relatively obscure.
Instead of seeing deep, blue skies, you see a sort of, you know, a milky sort of sky.
And around the sun, there'll be a very large aureole.
That is, light is scattered by the dust and it forms this large, lit, brilliant area around the sun, and it extends out quite a distance.
So it's quite apparent.
And I suppose down on the ground things get dusty.
Yes, yes.
But actually, most of the dust is carried at higher altitudes.
The dust typically in the Miami area will extend, oh, to 10, 12,000 feet.
And most of it is below that level; some will get higher.
But you may very well have the highest concentrations aloft within this what we call the Saharan air layer, which has very characteristic properties.
It's a dry, hot layer of air and it has a lot of dust in it.
We don't need aliens for that.
We could do it on our own.

The voters Republicans will depend on tomorrow include conservative evangelicals.
In 2004, these religious voters turned out in large numbers.
In 2006, their vote is being tracked by the man who will join us next, John Green, of the Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life.
He says Republicans may be affected by scandals, including the sex scandal involving a prominent Colorado minister, Ted Haggard.
It could, in fact, have a big impact on religious voters.
I suspect that where it may have the biggest effect is in Colorado, which is where Rev.
Haggard lives and where he is a very prominent figure - in fact, been very involved in the marriage amendment that's on the ballot there.
It may have an effect nationwide, although perhaps somewhat less, because Rev.
Haggard's not as deeply involved in the voter mobilization activities as some other Christian conservative leaders.
Do you expect that evangelical voters will turn out in huge numbers on Tuesday?

My sense is that right now, we'll probably see a fairly large turnout among evangelicals, and strong support for Republican congressional candidates - in large part because of an extraordinary effort that has been made to get them to the polls.
Is the message, to some degree, you may not like the Republicans, but there's really only one candidate running - you can't even consider voting for a Democrat in most cases?
In many ways, the message is exactly like that.
Despite the problems of certain Republicans, there really is no alternative from the point of view of the agenda of Christian conservatives.

Well, we see two things in polls.
One we see is in the measures of likely voters.
Christian conservatives look a whole lot like the rest of the country.
In other words, they look like they're going to vote at about the same rate as other Americans, and in fact, some surveys suggest, maybe vote at a little bit higher level.
And then if we look at the support for Republican candidates, such as in generic ballots and things, it looks a lot like 2002.
Down a little bit, but that could be accounted for by a lot of different issues.
Let's talk about how this might affect a specific race.

What is of significance here?

In fact, some of these issues, like abortion, appear in a variety of different forums on this voter guide.
I mean, they talk about the public funding of abortions, they talk about the parental notification for abortions by minors.

But it's interesting, there's also some economic issues that show up, and things that you would associate with the Republican Party, such as lower income taxes, reforming Social Security and so forth.
Is it fair to say that every single issue makes Allen look good, and every single issue makes Jim Webb look not so good?
I think one could draw that conclusion, that the particular issues that have been chosen really do differentiate the candidates.
For this particular audience.
For this particular audience, yes.
And one of the other interesting things about it is, in the column for Allen, there are always answers - he opposes, he supports a particular issue.
But, for Webb, there's many times no response.

As a young journalist, William E.
Peters was a pioneer in chronicling the turbulent years of the Civil Rights Movement in print and on television.
Mr. Peters died May 28th at age 85.

In August of 1956, Mr. Peters helped familiarize the nation with a 27-year-old minister from Atlanta, Georgia, Martin Luther King Jr. He wrote an article about Dr. King for Redbook magazine titled ""Our Weapon is Love"".
It was the first time that a national audience was introduced to Dr. King's philosophy of nonviolent resistance.
Mr.
Peters gained further renown years later for his Emmy Award-winning television documentary, ""A Class Divided"", aired on PBS, which was a follow-up to his film, ""Eye of the Storm"".
The documentaries focused on an exercise in discrimination, conducted in a third-grade class in Riceville, Iowa.
